data.title: 10mm magic bullets
data.meta_description: 1. I am looking for a general purpose round that will be respectable for self defense vs humans, potential self-defense vs black bears / cougars and...
data.text:
SharpDog

Bushwhacker

Joined

Aug 6, 2016

Messages

11,422

Likes

80,777

Location

It's a secret

#1

1. I am looking for a general purpose round that will be respectable for self defense vs humans, potential self-defense vs black bears / cougars and potential for subsistence hunting in an emergency

2. I don't reload and so reloading suggestions are interesting but not helpful.

3. 5" barrel semi-auto (xTen)

It looks like the 140 gr Underwood Extreme penetrator might do the trick. It is one of those funky Phillips head solid bullets moving out at about 1500 fps. Looks like lots of energy, good long and deep wound channel for the first half of the track and 30" of penetration.

Q: Is Underwood Extreme Penetrator such a magic round or should I stagger load one round of hard cast followed by a round of JHP ?. I consider this sub-optimal because of the extreme penetration of hardcast. If I do stagger load what do you recommend ?

Do you have another round that would be a better general purpose round ?

If I do go with Underwood, what is a suitable practice round ? The Underwood 135 gr. ?

Paulyseggs

Bushwhacker

Joined

Jan 28, 2018

Messages

10,824

Likes

45,579

Location

CT.

#2

I always like the 200gr jhp from Double tap. But I haven't owned a 10mm in over 10years. I'd probably go with a 200gr jhp from Buffalo Bore or Underwood.

Unless brown bears/moose/polar bears are a concern. Then I'd go with a hardcast bullet

Eta. IIRC Underwood has a XTP bullet load. That's always a deep penetration load for a JHP. I'd be happy with that

#3

I always like the 200gr jhp from Double tap. But I haven't owned a 10mm in over 10years. I'd probably go with a 200gr jhp from Buffalo Bore or Underwood.

Unless brown bears/moose/polar bears are a concern. Then I'd go with a hardcast bullet

The 200 JHP is definitely in the mix.

There was a YT video about some of the BB rounds having too long an OAL to function reliably in the xTen so I'm avoiding them for now.

There are other makers like Grizzly for instance but I don't know anything about them.

#4

First I have no experience with 10mm specifically, but like you, I spend a lot of time trying to find a general purpose load, and have gone through this process for .38, 9mm, and 45acp with regard to pistols.

I’ve decided that simple projectiles that I can afford to practice with, driven at velocities I can control are the simple answer.

I do handload, which I think is a very useful activity, so I’m not overly familiar with factory offerings, but it’s really all the same.

I’d be looking at 1k round cases of basic loads. Low tech wad cutters, heavy ball ammo or an affordable basic hollowpoint. Stuff like that.

Takings look at SGAmmo and pretending I have a 10mm, I might buy something like this after testing out a box.

Something reliable, not crazy hot, not too expensive. Good for 2 & 4 leg critters. Maybe I’d find an American brand just because.

My ammo preferences are a bit peculiar I suppose, but I’d rather have a thousand rounds of ball that I am familiar with than a few boxes of dollar-a-pop magic bullets.

Last edited: Dec 17, 2023

#6

I always like the 200gr jhp from Double tap. But I haven't owned a 10mm in over 10years. I'd probably go with a 200gr jhp from Buffalo Bore or Underwood.

Unless brown bears/moose/polar bears are a concern. Then I'd go with a hardcast bullet

Eta. IIRC Underwood has a XTP bullet load. That's always a deep penetration load for a JHP. I'd be happy with that

Underwood has the XTP in both 180 and 200. Black bears and especially cougars aren't that hard to kill. For general use from two legged varmints to the above mentioned critters, I carry my own load with XTP that duplicates the Underwood 180gr. In my 4.5" XDME, it's a very comfortable and accurate load.

10mm Auto 180gr. eXtreme Terminal Performance (XTP®) Jacketed Hollow Point Hunting & Self Defense Ammo

Underwood Ammo offers the most comprehensive and innovative Hornady® Supersonic Handgun Ammo for personal defense & hunting. Shop now 10mm Auto Brass ammo with Jacketed Hollow Point.

If I'm going to be around anything bigger, I go with 200 or 220 grain cast flat points.

I would not go with any of those extreme penetrator loads in 10mm for humans.

#12

No location listed but what type of critters do you anticipate? For lighter critters (under 250 lbs or so) I’d go with a faster expanding hollow points. For the big critters, I’d start to consider cast bullets with big meplats (as long as they feed well). Either way, I’d look for a comparable load(or handload), recoil wise, that you can afford to practice a lot. Shot placement first, bullet construction second, power third.

I'm in East TN so prolly 80 % - 90 % humans, possible other critters like wild dogs, etc. possible black bears or cougar. I would like the load to be suitable for deer hunting. Since I started the thread I have found some heavy 180 gr - 200 gr Federal and Winny JSP for sale but I'm still thinking the Underwood 140 Extreme series is like a .357 magnum +P if you will while the heavy 10mm JSPs are more like .45 ACP +P (maybe).

#16

In 10mm I would think that any good-quality JHP will be fine for anything you're likely to encounter in TN and is certainly going to be best as a general-purpose round. OK for deer, more than sufficient for defense, probably more than enough for the smaller bears or cats that pose a hazard (farfetched scenario IMO). Any deep penetration oriented round is just going exit the far side in the majority of situations which poses two problems, reduced volume of the wound channel leading to reduced lethality, and potential hazard to whatever is on the far side.

10mm JHP will not leave much left if you hit small game. I've always thought the old-time side-by-side shotguns with a third boring for a .22 rimfire or similar would be the right idea for shoot-whatever-you-see meat hunting, but I've never seen a modern version of them. The originals were heavy and unreliable. The idea is you keep to smaller gauge, 20, 28, .410, and keep the barrel short and the choke on the full side.

#17

Carry the Underwood Xtreme Penetrator in a Glock 40 long slide and it is quite the round...

For 2-leggers I prefer a 155-165 JHP in the 1200-1300 fps range.

In the woods a 200 grain cast in the 1150-1250 range much like this:

10MM 200 Grain Hardcast Lead Wide Nose (100 RND)

Free shipping on orders of 100 rounds and more 200 grain Hardcast Flat Point. Velocity: 1150 FPS. This is a nice balance of power and shootability. Extensively tested for reliable operation. This was developed using a Glock. Tested in XD and S&W handguns as well. Ammunition must go to a physical...

Never cared for the 180s in .40/10mm...never grouped as well in my 10s or .40s...

Bob

#18

Gold dot or HST would be my first choice for a do all defensive round for your listed purposes.

As a general rule, light for caliber bullets are something I avoid.

Alternating different loads in a magazine is just a bad idea due to different external ballistics of different bullets even in the same grain weight loadings. All this to say nothing of different powder charges and operating pressures for different rounds.

A reliable bonded jacketed hollowpoint should solve any possible problem from your listed possibilities. For heavier game or dangerous large animals I would simply load with heavy, moderate to high pressure hardcast bullets.

I can't speak for 10mm XTP but 9mm and .38spl XTP have a rep for not always having the most consistent or reliable expansion, especially out of a 3.5 inch barrel. Might be worth looking into short barrel specific jhp loads.

#20

I've thought a lot about this question, however I run .357 mag. That being said the same principles apply. As far as I can tell any bullet that will be "good" for bear is going to be "overkill" for 2 legged threats. If you're in the woods I'd run heavy hardcast, but if your in town light hollow points lessen the risk of over penetration. Currently I run 140 grain copper hollow points, they get good expansion and decent penetration, in my area black bears are rare, mountain lions are prevalent though. If I was in an area where bears were more common I'd run 180 or 200 grain hardcast and not look back. I would switch rounds back to hollow points of some flavor for town carry though, annoying but worth it IMHO.

#21

Speaking of XTP-HP bullets, Hornady increased the muzzle velocity of its 10mm 180grn ammo from 1180fps to 1275fps (650fpe) as derived from a 5” barrel:

I’ve shot a couple of boxes and it was very accurate. The uptick in velocity was noticeable but manageable if you shoot 10mm regularly.

Hornady’s website specifies the load’s application is for “personal defense” as well as hunting.

#22

For what you listed your intended uses for you can't beat the Underwood 180gr XTP load. These are proven to go over 1300fps out of my 5" Kimber 1911.

For practice rounds I've had great luck in power and accuracy with the Sellier and Bellot 180gr FMJ and their 180gr JHP. I actually like how the JHP is a very large opening compared to the XTP's.

"Tools and Targets" on YT just did a comparison video between BB and Underwood.......guess the winner of that one.

#23

I'm a bit leery of the 180 gr and especially lighter than that JHPs shedding mass at the higher velocity out of a 5" barrel. I would also like to have the ammo perform out of a possible future 8" barrel. I'm not opposed to just getting ball ammo for practice and woods use as @Dubhelix suggested.

I guess I'm down to six choices. In no particular order:

Federal 200 gr. JSP

Federal 200 gr. JHP HST

Winchester 200 gr JSP

Grizzly 200 gr JHP

Underwood 200 gr JHP XTP

Hornady 200 gr JHP XTP

Kinda leaning towards the Grizzly (@Paulyseggs )

#25

When I did reload 40+ years ago My favorite was a 9mm 125 Speer JSP rolling out at 1250 fps in my HK P7M8. I used a Lee Loader and we would have a loading party where we round-robined the loading between several of us. I have always thought JSPs were the all-around bullets. Mainly hunting bullets. I gradually have been won over by heavy for caliber bullets which give higher momentum & penetration given a constant bullet profile. Looks like 200 gr JSP at 1250 fps is doable in the 10 mm. 200 gr JHPs might be better for the potential humans, deer, hogs and dogs involved.
